## Introduction
Red Elderberry (Sambucus racemosa) is a native plant found in the Pacific Northwest region of North America. It is known for its medicinal and edible properties and has been used by indigenous communities for centuries. This article will explore the various uses and benefits of Red Elderberry.

## Plant Overview
Red Elderberry is a deciduous shrub that can grow up to 20 feet tall. It has compound leaves with 5-7 leaflets and produces clusters of small, white flowers in the spring. These flowers give way to bright red berries in the summer. The plant prefers moist, well-drained soils and is commonly found in forests, meadows, and along stream banks.

## Useful Properties
Red Elderberry is rich in antioxidants, vitamins, and minerals. The berries are a good source of vitamin C, vitamin A, and potassium. The plant also contains compounds such as flavonoids and anthocyanins, which have anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties.

## Traditional and Medicinal Uses
The indigenous people of the Pacific Northwest have long used Red Elderberry for its medicinal properties. The berries were traditionally used to treat colds, flu, and respiratory infections. The plant was also used as a diuretic and to promote sweating during fevers. The bark and leaves were used externally to soothe rashes, burns, and insect bites.

Modern herbalists continue to use Red Elderberry for its immune-boosting properties. It is often used to support the immune system during cold and flu season. The berries can be made into syrups, tinctures, or teas to help alleviate symptoms of respiratory infections. However, it is important to note that the berries must be cooked before consumption, as they can be toxic when raw.

## Nutritional Benefits
Red Elderberry berries are a good source of vitamin C, which is essential for immune function and collagen production. They also contain vitamin A, which is important for eye health and immune function. The berries are low in calories and fat, making them a healthy addition to a balanced diet.

## Practical Tips for Use
When using Red Elderberry, it is important to cook the berries before consuming them. This helps to remove any toxins and improve their taste. The berries can be used to make jams, jellies, syrups, and pies. The flowers can be used to make elderflower cordial or infused into teas. The bark and leaves can be used topically to soothe skin irritations.

When harvesting Red Elderberry, be sure to leave some berries on the plant for wildlife. Birds, in particular, rely on the berries as a food source. It is also important to properly identify the plant, as there are other species of elderberry that may be toxic.

## Pro Tips
- Red Elderberry is a great plant to incorporate into your garden to attract birds and other wildlife.
- The flowers can be used to make a delicious and refreshing elderflower soda.
- When foraging for Red Elderberry, be sure to wear gloves as the plant can cause skin irritation in some individuals.

## Summary
Red Elderberry is a versatile plant with both medicinal and edible uses. Its berries are rich in vitamins and antioxidants, making them a valuable addition to a healthy diet. The plant has a long history of traditional use by indigenous communities and continues to be used by herbalists today. When using Red Elderberry, it is important to cook the berries and properly identify the plant to ensure safe consumption.
